metadata.title: Convert Joules to Megajoules – Energy Converter
metadata.description: Convert energy from Joules (J) to Megajoules (MJ), useful for large energy quantities and power specifications.

introduction: This converter transforms joules to megajoules for large energy quantity expression.
Industrial energy specifications use megajoules for convenient large number handling.
This converter uses the relationship where 1 megajoule equals 1 million joules.
methodology: 1 MJ = 1,000,000 J. To convert joules to megajoules, divide by 1,000,000.
Large energy quantities expressed in MJ for readability and convenience.
Understanding joule to megajoule conversion is essential for energy planning.
This converter provides accurate energy conversion.
examples: Example 3 – Large explosion: 100 megajoules of energy.

faqs.question: What uses megajoules?
faqs.answer: Industrial processes, explosives, large machinery, power plant specifications.

faqs.question: How much is 1 megajoule?
faqs.answer: About 0.28 kilowatt-hours. Enough to power light bulb ~3 hours.

faqs.question: What's the relationship to kilowatt-hours?
faqs.answer: 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ. Power companies use kWh; physics uses joules.

faqs.question: How is TNT measured?
faqs.answer: TNT equivalent: 1 gram TNT ≈ 4.6 MJ. Explosives measured in kilotons/megatons TNT.

faqs.question: What's zero-point energy?
faqs.answer: Theoretical physics concept. Not relevant for practical energy calculations.

faqs.question: How do I calculate energy from power?
faqs.answer: Energy = Power × Time. 1000 watts × 1 hour = 3.6 MJ.

faqs.question: What's the highest energy source?
faqs.answer: Nuclear: ~100 million joules per gram of fuel. Far exceeds chemical.

faqs.question: Do I need to understand megajoules?
faqs.answer: Most people use kWh. Joules/megajoules matter for physics/engineering.

glossary.definition: British Thermal Unit. Legacy energy unit.
